sen.j: 上野 忠則（うえの ただのり、天正9年（1581年） - 没年不詳）は安土桃山時代から江戸時代の武将。
sen.e: Tadanori UENO (1581 - the year of death unknown) is a warlord in the periods of Azuchi-Momoyama to Edo.
Tadanori UENO (1581 - year of death unknown) was a warlord from the Azuchi-Momoyama to Edo periods.
Tadanori UENO (1581 - year of death unknown) was a military commander from the Azuchi-Momoyama to Edo periods.

sen.j: 島津氏の家臣。
sen.e: He was a retainer of the Shimazu clan.
He was a retainer of the Shimazu clan.
He was a retainer of the Shimazu clan.

sen.j: 幼名：千代太郎。
sen.e: His childhood name was Chiyotaro.
His childhood name was Chiyotaro.
His childhood name was Chiyotaro.

sen.j: 彦九郎。
sen.e: His name after attaining manhood was Hikokuro.
His name after attaining manhood was Hikokuro.
His name after attaining manhood was Hikokuro.

sen.j: 隼人佑。
sen.e: Hatyatonosuke

sen.j: 入道名は宗秋。
sen.e: His Buddhist name was 宗秋.
sen.cmt: 武士が「入道」した場合、「僧侶」になったと考えていいかどうかどうしても確認できませんでした。従って'priestly name'という表現でいいかどうか自信がなく、あいまいな表現ですが'Buddhist name'としました。あくまでも仮訳です。また入道名の「宗秋」ですが、「そうしゅう」なのか「むねあき」なのかが不明のため漢字のままとしました。
sen.e: His Buddhist name was 宗秋.
His Buddhist name was 宗秋.

sen.j: 上野忠元の子。
sen.e: The child of Tadamoto UENO
The child of Tadamoto UENO
The child of Tadamoto UENO

sen.j: 吉田衆中、上野隼人左（隼人佑とも）忠元の息子として生まれる。
sen.e: He was born as a son of Tadamoto Hayatonosuke UENO (Hayatonosuke: an official post name written as 隼人左 or 隼人佑), who belonged to Yoshida-shuju (吉田衆中: one of the Shimazu clan's squires' group of a locality called Yoshida.
He was born as a son of Tadamoto Hayatonosuke UENO (Hayatonosuke: an official post name written as 隼人左 or 隼人佑), who belonged to Yoshida-shuju.
He was born as a son of Tadamoto Hayatonosuke UENO (Hayatonosuke: an official post name written as 隼人左 or 隼人佑), who belonged to Yoshida-shuju.

sen.j: 忠元は元亀3年（1572年）の「木崎原の戦い」のときに米良重方を討ちとり、天正14年（1586年）「筑州筑岩高取城」攻めの評定のとき、島津義弘貴下である真幸院衆中の横目衆5人の内に数えられたがそこで戦没している。
sen.e: Tadamoto killed Shigetaka MERA in 'the Battle of Kizakibaru' in 1572 and he was nominated in a conference prior to the attack against 'Chikushu Chikugan Takatori-jo Castle' in 1586 to one of the five Yokome-shu (横目衆: superintendent officers) overseeing Mazakiin squires group which was subject to Yoshihiro SHIMAZU but lost his life in this battle.
sen.cmt: 「貴下」という言葉は辞書等にも出現せず確認はできていませんが、文脈から「支配下にある」と解釈しています。また「真幸院衆中の横目衆5人」の中の「の」の意味が、「のなかから選ばれる」のか「を監督するための」の意味なのかはっきりしませんが、ここでは後者の意味に解釈しました。
sen.e: Tadamoto killed Shigetaka MERA in 'the Battle of Kizakibaru' in 1572 and he was nominated in a conference prior to the attack against 'Chikushu Chikugan Takatori-jo Castle' in 1586 to one of the five superintendent officers overseeing Mazakiin squires group which was subject to Yoshihiro SHIMAZU but lost his life in this battle.

Tadamoto killed Shigetaka MERA in 'the Battle of Kizakibaru' in 1572 and he was nominated in a conference prior to the attack against 'Chikushu Chikugan Takatori-jo Castle' in 1586 to one of the five superintendent officers overseeing Mazakiin squires group which was subject to Yoshihiro SHIMAZU but lost his life in this battle.

sen.j: 忠則は文禄3年（1594年）12月10日に島津義弘の前で元服し、上野彦九郎と名乗る。
sen.e: Tadanori was celebrated his attainment of manhood before Yoshihiro SHIMAZU on December 10, 1594 and assumed the name Hikokuro UENO.
Tadanori celebrated his attainment of manhood before Yoshihiro SHIMAZU on December 10, 1594, and assumed the name Hikokuro UENO.
Tadanori celebrated his attainment of manhood before Yoshihiro SHIMAZU on December 10, 1594, and assumed the name Hikokuro UENO.

sen.j: その5日後には栗野に配されるが、すぐ様、衆中制に伴い須木村に移り須木地頭の村尾重侯の被官となる。
sen.e: Five days later he was dispatched to a place called Kurino but soon moved to Suki-mura village based on Shuju rule (the Shimazu clan's rule for locality-based grouping of squires) and became an official serving Shigeari MURAO, the local head person of Suki area.

Five days later he was dispatched to a place called Kurino but soon moved to Suki-mura village based on Shuju rule (the Shimazu clan's rule for locality-based grouping of squires) and became an official serving Shigeari MURAO, the local head person of Suki area.

Five days later he was dispatched to a place called Kurino but soon moved to Suki-mura village based on Shuju rule (the Shimazu clan's rule for locality-based grouping of squires) and became an official serving Shigeari MURAO, the local head person of Suki area.

sen.j: 須木は諸国へ通じる「八方境」であり、賊徒や辻切りなどに対応するため忠則は守護の番をする役目に就く。
sen.e: Suki was an important crossroads for traffics of every direction leading to various provinces, where he undertook the safeguarding of the area against thief gangs and tsujigiri (killing in the street to test a new sword).

Suki was an important crossroads for traffic of every direction leading to various provinces, where he undertook the safeguarding of the area against robber gangs and tsujigiri (killing in the street to test a new sword).

Suki was an important crossroads for traffic of every direction leading to various provinces, where he undertook the safeguarding of the area against robber gangs and tsujigiri (killing in the street to test a new sword).

sen.j: 慶長4年（1599年）の「庄内の乱」の際は村尾重侯、その息子の村尾重昌について6月21日に出陣。
sen.e: Tadanori took the field at the time of 'the Battle of Shonai' accompanying Shigeari MURAO and his son Shigemasa MURAO.
Tadanori took the field at the time of 'the Battle of Shonai' accompanying Shigeari MURAO and his son Shigemasa MURAO.
Tadanori took the field at the time of 'the Battle of Shonai' (1599) accompanying Shigeari MURAO and his son Shigemasa MURAO.

sen.j: 須木衆は2つの組に分けられ一隊は忠則、もう一隊は逆瀬川武安が指揮を任せられ6月23日に山田城（日向国）を包囲攻撃、10時間後に落城させる。
sen.e: The Suki soldiers, being divided into two groups - one led by Tadanori and the other by Takeyasu SAKASEGAWA - laid siege to Yamada-jo Castle (Hyuga Province, today's Miyazaki Prefecture) which surrendered in 10 hours.

The Suki soldiers, being divided into two groups - one led by Tadanori and the other by Takeyasu SAKASEGAWA - laid siege to Yamada-jo Castle (Hyuga Province, today's Miyazaki Prefecture) which surrendered in 10 hours.

The Suki soldiers, being divided into two groups - one led by Tadanori and the other by Takeyasu SAKASEGAWA - laid siege to Yamada-jo Castle (Hyuga Province, today's Miyazaki Prefecture) which surrendered in 10 hours.

sen.j: 忠則は城内に攻め入る際に武功をあげた。
sen.e: Tadanori rendered distinguished military service at the time of penetrating into the castle.
Tadanori rendered distinguished military service at the time of penetrating into the castle.
Tadanori rendered distinguished military service at the time of penetrating into the castle.

sen.j: その後、忠則と逆瀬川は伊集院忠真が降伏するまで山田城の普請奉行を務める。
sen.e: Tadanori and Sakasegawa held a post of construction magistrate in Yamada-jo Castle until Tadazane IJUIN gave in.
Tadanori and Sakasegawa held a post of construction magistrate in Yamada-jo Castle until Tadazane IJUIN gave in.
Tadanori and Sakasegawa held a post of construction magistrate in Yamada-jo Castle until Tadazane IJUIN gave in.

sen.j: 慶長5年（1600年）、「関ヶ原の戦い」から義弘が帰還する際は、村尾親子の率いた須木衆130人に加わり八代（現：東諸県郡国富町）に出迎えに行く。
sen.e: When Yoshihiro returned from 'the Battle of Sekigahara' in 1600, Tadanori went to Yatsushiro (today's Kunitomi-cho, Higashimorogata-gun) to meet him together with a company of 130 soldiers of Suki area led by Shigeari MURAO and his son.

When Yoshihiro returned from 'the Battle of Sekigahara' in 1600, Tadanori went to Yatsushiro (today's Kunitomi-cho, Higashimorogata-gun) to meet him together with a company of 130 soldiers from the Suki area led by Shigeari MURAO and his son.

When Yoshihiro returned from 'the Battle of Sekigahara' in 1600, Tadanori went to Yatsushiro (today's Kunitomi-cho, Higashimorogata-gun) to meet him together with a company of 130 soldiers from the Suki area led by Shigeari MURAO and his son.

sen.j: その帰りに木脇（現：国富町）にて伊東氏の家臣・稲津重政の番主の置かれた義門寺を攻撃。
sen.e: On their way back, they attacked Gimon-ji Temple where a defense troop of Shigemasa INAZU, a subordinate of the Ito clan, was deployed.
sen.cmt: 「番主」という言葉は辞書等にも出現せず、意味の確認ができていませんが、字面から「守護隊」と解釈しました。
sen.e: On their way back, they attacked Gimon-ji Temple where a defense troop of Shigemasa INAZU, a subordinate of the Ito clan, was deployed.
On their way back, in Kiwaki (today's Kunitomi-cho),they attacked Gimon-ji Temple where a defense troop of Shigemasa INAZU, a subordinate of the Ito clan, was deployed.

sen.j: 忠則は村尾重昌と共に敵将の仮屋原弥助を討ち取る武勲をあげる。
sen.e: Tadanori performed a meritorious deed of killing the enemy general Yasuke KARIYAHARA in cooperation with Shigemasa MURAO.
Tadanori performed a meritorious deed of killing the enemy general Yasuke KARIYAHARA in cooperation with Shigemasa MURAO.
Tadanori performed a meritorious deed of killing the enemy general Yasuke KARIYAHARA in cooperation with Shigemasa MURAO.

sen.j: 承応2年（1653年）、忠則73歳のときに「上野隼人覚書」を書き記す。
sen.e: Tadanori wrote 'Ueno Hayato Oboegaki' (Notes of Hayato UENO) in 1653 when he was 73.
sen.cmt: 「上野隼人覚書」の読み、定訳ともに不明です。
sen.e: Tadanori wrote 'Ueno Hayato Oboegaki' (Notes of Hayato UENO) in 1653 when he was 73.
Tadanori wrote 'Ueno Hayato Oboegaki' (Notes of Hayato UENO) in 1653 when he was 73.
